instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP5V_G3S: What is PP5V_G3S? PP5V_G3S is a 5v power rail present when the system is in a G3S standby state.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message:
This board has been to another shop, apparently they just cleaned it but didn't do any board repair.

5.23v on the amp meter and 0.000a.

Values in parentheses (diode mode)

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 1.2v and for about 10 secs drops down to 0.9v before looping back to 1.2v rinse repeat (0.460)
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> 5.12v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 0.161v (0.399)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_G3S</SIGNAL> 0v (0.298)

<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
<SIGNAL>CHGR_CSIR_N</SIGNAL> 5.12v (0.580)
<SIGNAL>CHGR_CSIR_P</SIGNAL> 5.12v (0.539)
<SIGNAL>CHGR_COMP</SIGNAL> 1.15v (0.573)
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> 0.7v slowly drops (0.364)
<SIGNAL>CHGR_AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 1.285v (0.575)
<SIGNAL>CHGR_LX1</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_LX2</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BOOT1</SIGNAL> 5.12v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_BOOT2</SIGNAL> 5.12v
<SIGNAL>PPCHGR_VDDA</SIGNAL> 5.12v
<SIGNAL>CHGR_CSOR_P</SIGNAL> 1.2v -> 0.9v cycle
<SIGNAL>CHGR_CSOR_N</SIGNAL> 1.2v -> 0.9v cycle

I did swap out <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and no difference, although I stupidly didn't record all the values beforehand other than 5v all over the place.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message:
We still need some voltage readings from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>: <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDP, <SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.
Also check resistance (ohm scale) over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 103184, member: 682"]
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>
[/QUOTE]
Looks like I need to lift the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to get a reading on <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> - is that correct?
<SIGNAL>CHGR_VDDP</SIGNAL>             5.12
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> seems to be an NC pin under <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, is that correct?
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_AMON</SIGNAL>             0v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H_CHGR_BMON</SIGNAL>             0.026v
<CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> 4.6 ohms between pins 1 and 2 (is this what you meant?)
<CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR> 33 ohms

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message:
Sorry, realised you meant the names of the U700 pins in the schematic as opposed to the net names on the boardview.

Looks like I need to lift the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> to get a reading on <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> - is that correct?
<SIGNAL>AUX_OK</SIGNAL> seems to be an NC pin under <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, is that correct?

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message:
I'm back working on this board after the Christmas break. I got the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> problem sorted out and back at 20v. Everything seemed ok after I removed a couple of the components and put them back in order to check some of the values you asked me to check.

The problem I now have with the board is one that I previously had but had somehow attributed it to <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> but realise now it had nothing to do with that and that I had replaced it unnecessarily, and thereby caused the above problems.

I found that L8750 had pretty much melted into the board, taken out CC774 and CC775 with it. The <SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> pads on all three of those components are gone.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3S</SIGNAL> at the moment reads 5V.

<SIGNAL>PP1V1_S3</SIGNAL> however is only 0.053 in diode mode (151 ohms to ground) and I'm not sure how to go about troubleshooting this. I have removed <CHIP>U8100</CHIP> and <CAPACITOR>C8102</CAPACITOR> and injected 1v into <SIGNAL>PP1V1_S3</SIGNAL> but nothing lit up under the thermal camera and only 0.01a was drawn on the DCPS. Any ideas?

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message:
You should compare diode mode reading on <SIGNAL>1V1_S3</SIGNAL> with good board.
You can't detect any heat signature injecting into 150 ohm to ground.
If the reading is really low, very likely bad CPU...

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message: Good board is 0.163 diode mode on <SIGNAL>1V1_S3</SIGNAL>.

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message:
There is a big difference.
CPU is the most sensitive component connected there...

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message: You think game over then or worth removing all the small components just to be sure?

threads.title: Liquid damaged <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no power, 5.230v, 0.000a
threads.message: All the caps, even RAM chips, are more resistant than CPU...
